# The basis : tidy data 

Designed for *facilitating* data science :  
</br>
</br>

**Tidy data**:  

* 1 row = 1 observation  
* 1 column = 1 variable


# The basis : tidy data 

* 1 row = 1 observation  
* 1 column = 1 variable

<div class = "col2">
Ex. Not Tidy:  

```{r, echo = FALSE}
data1 <- data.frame("ID" = 1:6, 
                    "t1" = rnorm(6,5.6), 
                    "t2" = rnorm(6,8.5),
                    "t3" = rnorm(6,6.8))
data1
```
</br>  
</br>
VS        Tidy:  
```{r, echo = FALSE}
data2= cbind.data.frame("ID" = 1:18, "time" = c(rep("t1",6), rep("t2",6),rep("t3",6)), "measure" = c(data1$t1, data1$t2, data1$t3))
data2[1:12,]
```
</div>


# Why Tidyverse ... ? -- Base R
```{r}
data1 <- data.frame("ID" = 1:6, 
                    "t1" = round(rnorm(6,5.6), 2), 
                    "t2" = round(rnorm(6,8.5), 2),
                    "t3" = round(rnorm(6,8.5), 2))
data1
```

# Why Tidyverse ... ? -- Base R
<div class = "col2">
```{r, echo = FALSE}
data1
```
</br>

```{r}
data2 <- cbind.data.frame("ID" = rep(1:6,3),
                          "time" =c(
                            rep("t1",6),
                            rep("t2",6),
                            rep("t3",6)),
                          "measure" = c(
                            data1$t1, 
                            data1$t2, 
                            data1$t3))
```

```{r}
data2
```


</div>

# Why Tidyverse ... ? -- Tidyr way
<div class = "col2">
```{r, echo = FALSE}
data1
```
</br>
</br>
</br>

```{r}
library(tidyr)
data2 <- gather(data1, 
                "t1", "t2", "t3",        # new key names (levels)
                key = "time",            # previous key name (factor name)
                value = "measure",       # to-assign values 
                factor_key = TRUE)       # saves as factor
```

```{r}
data2
```

</div>

But... *what* is a tibble ?

# A "tibble" data frame
https://tibble.tidyverse.org/
</br>  

>- *data.frames that are lazy and surly: they do less and complain more*  

>- *Modern reimagining of the data.frame, keeping what time has proven to be effective, and throwing out what is not.*  

>- *enhanced print() method* - "tbl_df" class 
```{r}
head(dplyr::starwars)
```

# A "tibble" data frame
* *enhanced print() method* - "tbl_df" class 
```{r}
print(dplyr::starwars)
# only prints as many rows and columns as fit on one screen, supplemented by a summary of the remaining rows and columns.
# reveals the type of each column: <chr> = character, <fct> = factor, <dbl> = 'double' (nowadays "numeric")
```

# A "tibble" data frame
* it never changes the type of the inputs (characters won't become factors by default)

<div class = "col2">
```{r}
df = data.frame(a = c("toto", "tutu"), 
                b = 1, 
                c = 1:2)
df
class(df$a)
```
</br>  

```{r}

dft = tibble(a = c("toto", "tutu"),
             b = 1, 
             c = 1:2)
dft
class(dft$a)
```


</div>

# A "tibble" data frame
* it never changes the names of variables
```{r}
data.frame(`a + b` = 1:5)
tibble(`a + b` = 1:5)

```

# A "tibble" data frame
* it never creates row.names()

* only vectors of length 1 are recycled

* columns are built sequentially : they can make use of columns created in the same call

<div class = "col2">

```{r}
x = "a"
data.frame(x = 1, y = x)

```
</br>  


```{r}
x = "a"
tibble(x = 1, y = x)
```


</div>



#Quelques fonctions de tidyr

*separate* : separate each cell in a column to make several colums

```{r echo = FALSE}

data1=tibble(country = c("A","A","B","B","C","C"),
            year=c(1999, 2000,1999, 2000,1999, 2000),
            rate=c("0.7K/19M","2K/20M","37K/172M","80K/173M","212K/1T","213K/1T"))
```

```{r echo = TRUE}
data1
```
```{r echo = TRUE}
separate (data1, rate, sep="/", into=c("cases","pop"))
```

# 
*unite* : collapse cells across several columns to make a single column

```{r echo = FALSE}
data2=tibble(country = c("A","A","B","B","C","C"),
            century=c("19","20","19","20","19","20"),
            year=c("99","00","99","00","99","00"))
```

```{r echo = TRUE}
data2
```
```{r echo = TRUE}
unite(data2, century, year, col="year", sep="")
```

# How to deal with NA values ?

*complete* : turn implicit missing values into explicit missing values.

```{r echo = FALSE}
data3 <- tibble(eleve = c("Thomas","Thomas", "Marie", "Tim"),
                matiere = c("Maths","Francais","Maths","Francais"),
                note = c(10,15,18,8))
```

```{r echo = TRUE}
data3
```
```{r echo = TRUE}
data3 = complete(data3, eleve, matiere)
data3
```

# 

We can replace the NA values with the argument **fill**, alist that for each variable supplies a single value to use instead of NA.

```{r echo = TRUE}
data3
```
```{r echo = TRUE}
data3 = complete(data3, eleve, matiere, fill=list(note=0))
data3
```
